g.text: Do Various Respirator Models Fit the Workers in the Norwegian
Department of Occupational Medicine, St. Olavs Hospital, Trondheim University Hospital, Trondheim, Norway
Department of Geoscience and Petroleum, NTNU, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, Norway
the Artic University of Norway, Troms√∏, Norway
Department of Occupational and Environmental Medicine, University Hospital of North Norway, Troms√∏, Norway
the Artic University of Norway, Troms√∏, Norway
a r t i c l e i n f o
a b s t r a c t
Respirator Ô¨Åt testing is a method to assess if the respirator provides an adequate face seal
Workers from four Norwegian smelters were invited to participate in the study, and 701
respirator Ô¨Åt tests were performed on 127 workers. Fourteen respirator models were included: one
FFABE1P3 and 11 FFP3 respirator models produced in one size and two silicone half masks with P3 Ô¨Ålters
available in three sizes. The workers performed a quantitative Ô¨Åt test according to Health and Safety
6 different respirator models, and they rated the respirators based on comfort.
Predictors of overall Ô¨Åt factors were explored.
The pass rate for all Ô¨Åt tests was 62%, 56% for women, and 63% for men. The silicone respirators
had the highest percentage of passed tests (92
100%). The pass rate for the FFP3 models varied from 19
89%, whereas the FFABE1P3 respirator had a pass rate of 36%. Five workers did not pass with any
respirators, and 14 passed with all the respirators tested. Only 63% passed the test with the respirator
they normally used. The mean comfort score on the scale from 1 to 5 was 3.2. The respirator model was
the strongest predictor of the overall Ô¨Åt factor. The other predictors (age, sex, and comfort score) did not
improve the Ô¨Åt of the model.
There were large differences in how well the different respirator models Ô¨Åtted the Norwe-
gian smelter workers. The results can be useful when choosing which respirators to include in respirator
Ô¨Åt testing programs in similar populations.

The smelting industry has been, and still is, an important area of
employment in Norway. In 2016, Norway was the world‚Äôs third
largest producer of ferrosilicon and the second largest producer of
fumes, and gases are released into the work environment, and
depending on the type of production, they may contain potentially
harmful components such as quartz, cristobalite, amorphous silica,
heavy metals, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, and ultraÔ¨Åne
. Earlier studies have shown an accelerated
decreased lung function and increased risk of respiratory diseases
among workers in the Norwegian smelting industry
Although the exposure levels in Norwegian smelters have declined
owing to technical and organizational measures, they are still too
high in some areas, thereby requiring mandatory use of respirators.
It is important to ensure that the respirators used are suitable and
provide the workers with the protection they expect. Respirator Ô¨Åt
testing is a method of ensuring that the respirator Ô¨Åts the face of the
worker, that is, that the respirator provides an adequate face seal.
There are several Ô¨Åt test methods available, and respirator Ô¨Åt
testing using a specialized condensation particle counter Porta-
count Pro (TSI inc, Shoreview, MN, USA) is commonly used. This
instrument measures the ratio of ambient aerosols outside and
inside the respirator, while the wearer performs exercises accord-
ing to a deÔ¨Åned protocol. The various protocols have different
